queries.company_overview:
What it does: Shopify provides commerce infrastructure for businesses to start, run, and scale online and offline stores, combining subscription software with merchant services like payments, checkout, capital, and POS.
Main business units / segments:
- Subscription Solutions (plans, storefront, themes, apps, domains)
- Merchant Solutions (Shopify Payments/Shop Pay, Capital, POS, shipping, transaction fees)
- Shopify Plus (enterprise-grade capabilities and support)
- Point-of-Sale (POS) hardware and retail software
- Shop App and buyer network (Shop Pay Installments, Shop Campaigns)
High-level financials: FY2024 revenue $8.88B; FY2024 net income $2.02B (USD). Market capitalization as of 2025-11-03: $225.46B (USD).
Competitive positioning: Shopify competes with WooCommerce, BigCommerce, Adobe Commerce (Magento), Salesforce Commerce Cloud, and SMB website builders like Wix and Squarespace; in payments, it faces Stripe and Adyen. It reports >12% share of US ecommerce in 2024 and 64% GMV penetration for Shopify Payments in Q4 2024, underscoring scale and integrated checkout advantages. The company is expanding enterprise reach via Shopify Plus and omnichannel POS.
Recent major news:
- 2025-08-06 Shopify reports Q2 2025 results: 31% revenue growth and 16% free cash flow margin.
- 2025-06-18 Shopify announces 2025 annual meeting results; directors elected and PwC appointed auditors.
- 2025-05-08 Shopify reports Q1 2025 results: 27% revenue growth and 15% free cash flow margin.
- 2025-03-18 Shopify to transfer U.S. listing to Nasdaq from NYSE; TSX unchanged.
- 2025-02-11 Shopify reports Q4/FY2024: revenue $8.88B and net income $2.02B.

How will Shopify defend checkout share a.query: How will Shopify defend checkout share against Amazon's Buy with Prime on merchant sites?
How will Shopify defend checkout share a.answer: Shopify is defending checkout share by integrating Buy with Prime as a native app that routes Prime purchases through Shopify Checkout, processed by Shopify Payments, keeping transactions on Shopify’s rails. Merchants retain 100% control of brand and customer data and see synced orders in Shopify admin, while Amazon Pay is offered as a wallet option—letting merchants offer Prime benefits without ceding checkout to Amazon.

search_results.title: Shopify merchants can soon choose to offer Buy with Prime directly within their Shopify Checkout
search_results.snippet: Shopify says Amazon will release a Buy with Prime app that plugs into Shopify Checkout and is processed by Shopify Payments, so merchants can offer Prime shipping and returns while keeping 100% control of their brand and customer data within Shopify admin.

search_results.title: E-commerce rivals Amazon and Shopify reach truce on 'Buy with Prime' integration
search_results.snippet: GeekWire reports that Prime members can use payment methods from their Amazon wallets on Shopify sites, but Shopify processes the payment through its own checkout; Amazon Pay becomes a wallet option inside Shopify Payments, and merchants keep control of brand and customer data.

search_results.title: Shopify Unblocks Amazon’s Buy With Prime
search_results.snippet: Marketplace Pulse notes Shopify unblocked Buy with Prime after Amazon agreed to route BwP payments via Shopify Payments and add order/catalog syncing in Shopify admin—meaning Shopify retains payment processing and data visibility while Amazon expands logistics, keeping checkout inside Shopify.

What contingencies has Shopify prepared.query: What contingencies has Shopify prepared if Stripe partnership terms materially worsen during 2026?
What contingencies has Shopify prepared.answer: Shopify’s contract with Stripe includes a 90‑day termination right if unforeseen third‑party terms materially adversely affect Shopify or undo the commercial bargain, with Stripe required to provide reasonable wind‑down assistance—giving Shopify a legal off‑ramp if economics worsen. Operationally, Shopify’s payments stack is designed to swap or add processors: its Payments Platform lets third‑party gateways integrate as apps into checkout, and the company already supports 100+ payment providers globally. In practice, Shopify could exercise contractual protections and migrate merchants to alternative processors/gateways if Stripe terms deteriorate in 2026.

search_results.title: Payment Services Provider Agreement (EX-10.11)
search_results.snippet: The Stripe–Shopify USA agreement gives either party a 90‑day termination right if unforeseen Third Party Terms cause a material adverse effect on Shopify or undo the essential commercial bargain, and requires Stripe to allow time and provide reasonable assistance for a wind‑down. The deal also outlines migration procedures for merchants and notes Shopify may make other card processors available to merchants who do not use Shopify Payments.

search_results.title: Online payment gateways and payment provider integrations
search_results.snippet: Shopify states it supports integrations with over 100 payment providers worldwide beyond Shopify Payments. This demonstrates operational optionality to route payments through alternative gateways by country/region if primary processor terms become unfavorable.

search_results.title: All of the Announcements From Shopify Unite 2021
search_results.snippet: Shopify introduced a new Payments Platform that replaces legacy integration points and enables third‑party payment gateways to be created as Shopify apps integrated into checkout. This architecture allows Shopify to add or switch processors quickly, supporting contingency plans if a key partner’s terms worsen.

When will Shopify Sidekick AI reach gene.query: When will Shopify Sidekick AI reach general availability for all merchants and languages?
When will Shopify Sidekick AI reach gene.answer: Shopify Sidekick began rolling out to all merchants (English-only) with the Winter ’25 Edition in December 2024. Multilingual general availability followed in Summer ’25: by May 21, 2025, Sidekick supported all 20 languages available in the Shopify admin. In short, Sidekick is now broadly available to all merchants and across supported languages.

search_results.title: How Shopify’s Next Edition Makes Boring Upgrades Anything But
search_results.snippet: Shopify’s Winter ’25 blog confirms that Sidekick is “rolling out in English only, for all merchants,” marking platform‑wide availability starting December 2024 (English‑only) under the Winter ’25 release.

search_results.title: Expanding your AI Horizons, Summer '25 Edition
search_results.snippet: In Shopify’s Summer ’25 update, the company states that Sidekick now speaks all 20 languages supported in the Shopify admin and adds voice chat and screen share—confirming multilingual availability by May 21, 2025.

search_results.title: Shopify’s AI powered commerce assistant Sidekick expands across Europe, now supporting 20 languages
search_results.snippet: Retail Technology Innovation Hub reports Sidekick expanded from English to 20 supported languages, auto‑detecting and responding in a merchant’s language, with broad European language coverage—evidence of a multilingual rollout in early 2025.

What are Shopify's 2025-2026 plans for d.query: What are Shopify's 2025-2026 plans for developing proprietary language models powering Sidekick?
What are Shopify's 2025-2026 plans for d.answer: Public sources do not show Shopify planning to build proprietary foundation LLMs for Sidekick in 2025–2026. Instead, Shopify is fine-tuning and operating open-source and third-party models while investing in agentic architecture, LLM-as-judge evaluation, and reinforcement learning (GRPO) to specialize Sidekick for commerce. Shopify Engineering explicitly notes fine-tuning open-source LLMs (e.g., LlaVA, Llama 3.2, Qwen2VL), and prior coverage states Shopify pairs its proprietary data with available models like OpenAI’s ChatGPT.

search_results.title: Leveraging multimodal LLMs for Shopify’s global catalogue: Recap of expo talk at ICLR 2025
search_results.snippet: Shopify details a strategy of fine-tuning smaller open-source vision LLMs—not training proprietary foundation models—to power large-scale commerce tasks. The team reports moving across LlaVA 1.5 7B, Llama 3.2 11B, and Qwen2VL 7B for better accuracy, cost, and control, supporting ~40M multimodal LLM inferences daily across search, recommendations, and conversational commerce like Sidekick.

search_results.title: Building production-ready agentic systems: Lessons from Shopify Sidekick
search_results.snippet: This 2025 engineering post outlines Sidekick’s agentic architecture and Shopify’s focus on LLM-based evaluation and GRPO reinforcement learning to improve reasoning and actions. It emphasizes modular prompts, LLM judges calibrated to humans, user simulators, and iterative training—pointing to specialization and evaluation on top of existing models rather than building a proprietary base model.

search_results.title: Shopify Sidekick is like ChatGPT, but for e-commerce merchants
search_results.snippet: TechCrunch quoted Shopify’s AI lead saying Magic/Sidekick are powered by Shopify’s proprietary data paired with available LLMs like OpenAI’s ChatGPT, architected to avoid sharing merchant data externally. This supports that Shopify relies on third‑party models combined with its data, with no claim of building proprietary foundation LLMs.

Will Shopify expand Shop Ads or Shop Cam.query: Will Shopify expand Shop Ads or Shop Campaigns internationally in 2026 to drive monetization?
Will Shopify expand Shop Ads or Shop Cam.answer: No public timeline has been announced. As of now, Shop Campaigns (Shop Ads) are limited to the United States and Canada, with Canada added in mid-2024. Shopify has not disclosed a 2026 international rollout; any broader expansion remains unannounced.

search_results.title: Shop Campaigns eligibility — Shopify Help Center
search_results.snippet: Shop Campaigns can target customers in the United States or Canada only, and participating stores must be located in the U.S. or Canada with a Shopify Payments account in USD or CAD. To advertise to customers outside a store’s primary market (e.g., U.S. store targeting Canada), international sales tools must be enabled. No additional countries are listed.

search_results.title: Shop Cash and Shop Campaigns are now available to Canadian buyers and merchants
search_results.snippet: On June 24, 2024, Shopify expanded Shop Cash and Shop Campaigns beyond the U.S. to include Canada. Previously, only U.S. buyers and merchants could participate; after the update, both U.S. and Canadian merchants can target buyers in both countries. No expansion beyond the U.S. and Canada is noted.

search_results.title: Shopify Launches Its Ad Product to All Merchants
search_results.snippet: Adweek reports that Shopify made its Shop Campaigns ad product available to all merchants in the U.S. and Canada, buying ads on behalf of brands to acquire customers across Meta, Google, and the Shop app. The piece highlights the U.S./Canada availability and does not detail a wider international rollout timeline.

What specific 2026 initiatives will Shop.query: What specific 2026 initiatives will Shopify deploy to reduce churn among Shopify Plus enterprises?
What specific 2026 initiatives will Shop.answer: Shopify has not announced a 2026-specific, standalone churn-reduction program for Shopify Plus enterprises. Public roadmaps show 2026-dated platform changes designed to harden checkout and expand enterprise/B2B capabilities—most notably the enforced migration from Scripts to Shopify Functions by June 30, 2026 and new 2026-01 API features like ACH for B2B payments—which should improve performance, control, and stickiness. Separately, Shopify continues to promote retention tooling (personalization, omnichannel loyalty, proactive support) for enterprises, but these are ongoing rather than 2026-specific initiatives.

search_results.title: Shopify Scripts Deprecation
search_results.snippet: Shopify extended the Scripts deprecation deadline to June 30, 2026 and directs merchants to replace legacy Scripts using Shopify Functions for discounts, shipping, and payments. A Scripts customizations report helps plan migrations, with existing Scripts supported only until the new end date.

search_results.title: New ACH support for deferred payments
search_results.snippet: In the 2026-01 Admin GraphQL API, Shopify adds ACH bank account payments to the PaymentInstrument and CustomerPaymentInstrument unions for B2B company locations, enabling payment terms and draft orders. Enterprises managing B2B payment lifecycles are advised to upgrade to use these methods.

search_results.title: How to Improve Ecommerce Customer Retention
search_results.snippet: Shopify’s enterprise blog details retention tactics—personalized storefronts using unified customer data, customer segments, omnichannel loyalty integrated with POS, and proactive support—aimed at improving repeat purchase rates and lowering churn across enterprise commerce.

Is Shopify planning near-term changes to.query: Is Shopify planning near-term changes to subscription pricing across Basic, Shopify, and Advanced plans?
Is Shopify planning near-term changes to.answer: No. Management guidance indicates no near-term price increases for Shopify’s standard subscriptions in 2025. The CFO said subscription growth would reflect the shift back to three‑month paid trials and a lack of substantive pricing changes, while current plan rates remain posted on Shopify’s pricing page; recent earnings commentary centers on trials rather than raising prices.

search_results.title: Shopify CFO Says Expect The Move To 3-month Trials And Lack Of Substantive Pricing Changes In 2025 To Impact Subscription Solutions Growth
search_results.snippet: On Feb 11, 2025, a Benzinga brief reported Shopify’s CFO expects the shift back to three‑month paid trials and a lack of substantive pricing changes in 2025 to shape Subscription Solutions growth—signaling no near‑term price hikes for core plans.

search_results.title: Shopify (SHOP) Q4 2024 Earnings Call Transcript
search_results.snippet: On the Feb 11, 2025 call, management said they are moving to three‑month paid trials in most geographies, which would weigh on near‑term MRR comparisons; the discussion emphasizes trial length changes rather than raising prices on standard plans.

search_results.title: Pricing
search_results.snippet: Shopify’s current pricing page lists Basic (from $29/month billed annually; $39 month‑to‑month), Grow (from $79; $105 monthly), and Advanced (from $299; $399 monthly), along with a $1 for 3 months promo—showing present rates without announcing upcoming changes.

How prepared is Shopify for EU PSD3 and.query: How prepared is Shopify for EU PSD3 and PSR changes impacting payments routing and surcharging?
How prepared is Shopify for EU PSD3 and.answer: Shopify appears well positioned largely via its payments infrastructure: Stripe has published PSD3/PSR guidance and is building compliant flows for platforms, including SCA updates, so merchants processing through Shopify Payments/Stripe should inherit compliance. For routing, Stripe’s co‑badged card rules automatically present brand‑choice in hosted checkout UIs, covering EU network selection requirements. For surcharging, Shopify’s checkout doesn’t support adding payment‑method card surcharges, so little change is expected on that front for EU consumer payments.

search_results.title: A guide to PSD3 | Stripe
search_results.snippet: Stripe explains the EU’s proposed PSD3/PSR, key changes (uniform rules via PSR, tighter platform rules, updated SCA/transaction monitoring, greater fraud liability), and how platforms can rely on Stripe Connect to minimize licensing burden. It notes negotiations are ongoing and final rules aren’t expected to take effect before 2026, with Stripe updating authentication flows to help businesses stay compliant.

search_results.title: Co-badged cards compliance | Stripe Documentation
search_results.snippet: Stripe details the EU requirement to honor cardholder brand choice on co‑badged cards (e.g., Cartes Bancaires + Visa/Mastercard) and shows that Stripe Checkout/Elements automatically display a network selector when applicable. It explains how to set a default network and how to identify which network processed the charge—covering the routing/brand‑choice obligation relevant in the EU.

search_results.title: How can I display credit card surcharges at checkout? | Shopify Community
search_results.snippet: Shopify staff confirm it’s not possible to apply a credit card surcharge in Shopify checkout via the admin, and apps can’t add fees by payment method because the selected method isn’t exposed during checkout. Only indirect workarounds (e.g., handling fees via shipping) are suggested, indicating Shopify doesn’t natively support per‑card surcharging.

What revenue contribution does Shopify e.answer: Shopify has not disclosed a 2026 target for Europe or APAC’s share of revenue. search_results.snippet: Shopify reports growth accelerating across North America, Europe, and APAC; Europe was a particular source of strength, with GMV up 42% on a constant-currency basis. The release provides no 2026 regional revenue mix or contribution targets.

search_results.snippet: Ahead of its Investor Day, Shopify stated it would not provide a detailed long‑term financial model, implying no formal forecasts for items like 2026 Europe/APAC revenue contribution.

search_results.snippet: Latest disclosed geographic sales mix (2024) shows United States ~$5.71B (~64%), EMEA ~$1.71B (~19%), APAC ~$885M (~10%), Canada ~$483M, Latin America ~$97M; the page does not include any 2026 expectations.

What 2026 gross margin improvements does.query: What 2026 gross margin improvements does Shopify expect from renegotiating card network and processor fees?
What 2026 gross margin improvements does.answer: Shopify has not disclosed a specific, quantified 2026 gross margin uplift from renegotiating card-network and processor fees. Management has said that as key payments contracts (e.g., with Stripe, Adyen and PayPal) come up for renewal, they expect potential tailwinds to gross margin, though card-network cost changes could offset some benefits. In recent disclosures, Shopify reiterated that payments mix and processing economics drive gross margin, but provided no 2026 basis-point target tied to renegotiations.

search_results.title: Shopify Inc. Q1 2024 Morgan Stanley conference transcript
search_results.snippet: CFO Jeff Hoffmeister explained that payments growth is a gross margin headwind, but noted that as contracts with Stripe, Adyen and PayPal come up for renewal there may be tailwinds; he also cautioned that card-network cost changes could be headwinds. Management did not quantify a specific improvement.

search_results.title: Earnings call: Shopify reports strong Q3 growth, GMV up 24%
search_results.snippet: The Q3 call highlights that the expanded PayPal integration may increase revenue but impact margins, while payments penetration reached 62% of GMV. This underscores how processor terms affect gross margin; Shopify did not provide a numeric 2026 uplift from any renegotiations.

search_results.title: Shopify Announces Second-Quarter 2024 Financial Results
search_results.snippet: Shopify reported Q2 2024 gross margin of 51.1%, driven by the absence of logistics dilution and pricing changes, partially offset by growth of lower-margin payments. The release shows payments economics drive margin sensitivity, but it does not quantify any 2026 benefit from card-network or processor renegotiations.

What is Shopify's 2026 Shopify Payments.query: What is Shopify's 2026 Shopify Payments take rate target and planned actions to achieve it?
What is Shopify's 2026 Shopify Payments.answer: Shopify has not published a specific FY2026 take rate target for Shopify Payments. Instead, management focuses on lifting overall monetization and payments penetration. Actions include expanding Shopify Payments to more countries, deepening Shop Pay usage (41% of GPV in Q4’24), integrating additional wallets/local methods (e.g., PayPal, Klarna) and growing enterprise, B2B, and offline POS adoption—efforts that have already raised GPV penetration from 58% in 2023 to 62% in 2024 and 64% in Q1’25.

search_results.title: EarningsCall · SHOP Q4 2024
search_results.snippet: On the Q4’24 call, management said GPV penetration for the year was 62% (up from 58% in 2023), with Shop Pay accounting for 41% of GPV in the quarter. They attributed higher payments mix to more Plus merchants using Shopify Payments, broader geographic adoption of payments, and deeper Shop Pay penetration—emphasizing continued expansion rather than a fixed take rate target.

search_results.title: Shopify Q1 2025 slides: revenue jumps 27% as payments penetration hits 64% By Investing.com
search_results.snippet: Shopify’s Q1’25 investor slides show payments penetration reached 64% (up from 60% in Q1’24), equating to $47.5B of GPV. The presentation highlights growth vectors—international expansion (expanding payment capabilities across regions), offline commerce, enterprise and B2B—which underpin rising payments mix rather than disclosing a 2026 take rate figure.

search_results.title: Operations — We are building Shopify responsibly (Investor Day 2023)
search_results.snippet: Investor Day slides define product attach rate (total revenue/GMV) and show it rising to ~2.84% in 2023E, while GPV (payments penetration) climbed from ~42% in 2019 to ~57% in 2023 YTD. The emphasis is on increasing monetization via attach and payments penetration, not on a disclosed FY26 payments take rate target.

What new checkout experiments will Shopi.query: What new checkout experiments will Shopify run in 2026 to increase conversion rates?
What new checkout experiments will Shopi.answer: Shopify hasn’t published a specific list of “checkout experiments” for 2026. Official guidance shows 2026 will center on completing the migration to Checkout Extensibility and Shopify Functions (with Scripts ending June 30, 2026), while Shopify continues innovating around Shop Pay and the high‑converting checkout foundation. These capabilities enable merchants to experiment with payments, discounts, shipping logic, and pre/post‑purchase offers to improve conversion.

search_results.title: Shopify Scripts Deprecation
search_results.snippet: Shopify extended the Scripts deprecation deadline to June 30, 2026 and is enhancing Shopify Functions for discounts, shipping, and payments. Merchants are urged to migrate from Scripts to Functions, aligning checkout customizations with upgrade‑safe extensibility that underpins ongoing optimization of the checkout experience.

search_results.title: Shopify Checkout is the best-converting in the world. Here's why.
search_results.snippet: Shopify reports its checkout converts up to 36% better than competitors (15% on average), with Shop Pay lifting conversion by up to 50% versus guest checkout and delivering a 5% lower‑funnel lift by its presence alone. Shopify attributes this to its identity network, scale, consumer trust, and a high velocity of checkout innovation.

search_results.title: Technologies for customizing Shopify checkout
search_results.snippet: Shopify outlines how to customize checkout via Checkout UI extensions, post‑purchase extensions, Shopify Functions, and web pixel extensions. Use cases include pre/post‑purchase offers, additional fields and validation, and sorting payment/delivery options—practical levers merchants can test and iterate to improve conversion within Checkout Extensibility.

How will Shopify counter Adobe Commerce.query: How will Shopify counter Adobe Commerce and Salesforce Commerce Cloud in regulated industries?
How will Shopify counter Adobe Commerce.answer: Shopify will compete by proving it can meet stringent regulatory and data residency requirements while offloading compliance burden at the platform level. It has already delivered a Canada-only regional instance for the legal cannabis rollout (with PCI-compliant payments and controls to keep personal data in-country), and it maintains audited PCI DSS and SOC 3 reports that regulated merchants rely on. In healthcare, Shopify’s policy prohibits PHI on-platform, so its counter is to act as the commerce layer while sensitive data remains in compliant third-party systems or systems of record.

search_results.title: Engineering a Historic Moment: Shopify Gets Ready for Cannabis in Canada
search_results.snippet: For Canada’s cannabis legalization, Shopify created a Canada-only instance on Google Cloud (Montreal), added PCI-compliant payments and a regional data warehouse, and enforced multiple layers of app, host, and network controls so personal information stayed in Canada—launching provincial stores with zero downtime. Shopify notes these learnings and technologies will be reused to support future regulated markets.

search_results.title: Compliance Reports
search_results.snippet: Shopify publishes current, audited compliance attestations, including a 2025–2026 PCI DSS Attestation of Compliance, quarterly PCI ASV scan attestations, and 2024–2025 SOC 3 reports. These public reports evidence platform-level controls many regulated merchants require and reduce merchants’ own compliance burden.

search_results.title: Shopify Acceptable Use Policy
search_results.snippet: Shopify states merchants must comply with applicable laws and that certain activities are not supported—explicitly including uploading Protected Health Information subject to HIPAA. How is Shopify adapting to third-party c.query: How is Shopify adapting to third-party cookie deprecation and emerging privacy regulations in 2026?
How is Shopify adapting to third-party c.answer: Shopify is phasing out its own analytics/session cookies and shifting tracking to consent-aware, first-party mechanisms. From January 1, 2026, Shopify will stop setting _shopify_y and _shopify_s on storefronts, directing developers to use Web Pixels (e.g., event.clientId) and documented APIs instead of reading cookies. Its Customer Privacy API applies granular consent (analytics, marketing, preferences, sale of data) across pixels, audiences, and checkout, supports region-based banners and GPC, and ensures pixels only load and send events when permission is granted—aligning with GDPR/CPRA-style rules and a cookieless future.

search_results.title: _shopify_y and _shopify_s cookies will no longer be set
search_results.snippet: Starting January 1, 2026, Shopify will stop setting _shopify_s and _shopify_y on merchant storefronts. Code that reads these cookies must migrate to documented APIs: use Web Pixels and the clientId for what _shopify_y represented; there’s no direct replacement for _shopify_s, though a session-length cookie can be created via browser or the Web Pixels API. This change moves away from cookie reliance ahead of stricter privacy regimes.

search_results.title: Customer Privacy API
search_results.snippet: Shopify’s browser-based API verifies allowed data processing and registers consent for analytics, marketing, preferences, and data sale/sharing. Consent decisions apply to Shopify-managed surfaces like pixels, audiences, and checkout. The docs emphasize never reading cookies directly, using methods like analyticsProcessingAllowed/marketingAllowed and setTrackingConsent, supporting region-based banners and Global Privacy Control—facilitating GDPR/CPRA-style compliance.

search_results.title: Pixel Privacy
search_results.snippet: To meet international privacy rules, app and custom pixels declare required permissions and only load when the visitor’s consent allows it. Pixels can read initial consent (init.customerPrivacy) and subscribe to visitorConsentCollected via the Web Pixels API, ensuring events only fire when permitted. This consent-aware, sandboxed pixel model replaces brittle cookie tactics with first-party, privacy-respecting tracking.

Most notably, Shopify Protect shifts liability for eligible US Shop Pay orders by covering fraud/unrecognized chargebacks (including fees) and handling the dispute process, reinforced by built‑in fraud analysis, AVS checks, and operational best practices to prevent scam-driven disputes.

search_results.title: 9 Ways to Prevent Chargebacks for Your Business
search_results.snippet: Shopify frames prevention and response around current network rules—explicitly citing Visa’s Compelling Evidence 3.0 as a way to overturn first-party fraud by providing two prior undisputed purchases and matching device/IP—and pairs this with platform tools: built‑in fraud analysis, AVS guidance, Shopify Flow automations, and Shopify Payments’ automatic dispute evidence. It also recommends fast refunds, clear billing descriptors, digital receipts, and shipping best practices, and highlights Shopify Protect to shift fraud-chargeback liability on eligible Shop Pay orders.

search_results.title: Chargeback Protection for Merchants | Shopify Protect
search_results.snippet: Shopify Protect is free, built-in chargeback protection for eligible US Shop Pay transactions: orders marked “protection active” are safe to fulfill, and Shopify covers the total order cost and chargeback fee for fraud-based disputes while managing the dispute process. It uses network-wide fraud algorithms, requires timely fulfillment with supported carrier tracking, and extends coverage to Shop Pay transactions across channels like Facebook, Instagram, and Google.

search_results.title: Addressing chargebacks with Shopify Protect
search_results.snippet: For protected orders with fraudulent or unrecognized chargebacks, Shopify immediately credits back the disputed amount and fee and handles the dispute; if the bank later rules for the merchant, the credit is reversed. Unprotected orders follow the typical chargeback process, and non-fraud reasons (e.g., item not received, not as described) aren’t covered—clarifying how Shopify mitigates scam-related and first‑party fraud surges while aligning with chargeback categories and processes.

How will Shopify handle 2026 cross-borde.query: How will Shopify handle 2026 cross-border tax changes including DAC7 and marketplace facilitator rules?
How will Shopify handle 2026 cross-borde.answer: By 2026, Shopify handles U.S. marketplace-facilitator obligations through the Shop app: it automatically collects, remits, and files taxes on Shop-channel orders, while merchants still may need to include those transactions in state filings where required. For cross‑border VAT and duties, Shopify’s Managed Markets (with Global‑e as merchant of record) remits local taxes and manages import taxes on behalf of merchants, removing the need for local tax registrations. In the EU, DAC7 obliges platform operators to collect, verify, and annually report seller data; where Shopify’s platform services fall in scope, it must adhere to DAC7’s due‑diligence and reporting timelines.

search_results.title: Sales tax in Shop
search_results.snippet: Shopify confirms that from January 1, 2025, the Shop channel automatically collects, remits, and files U.S. taxes on Shop‑app orders in all sales‑tax states (plus Alaska local tax). Marketplace tax is deducted from Shopify Payments payouts and marked as Filed by channel in reports; item‑level refunds are required to refund tax, and tax collection certificates (SC Commerce Services Inc.) are available via Support.

search_results.title: Managed Markets
search_results.snippet: Shopify’s Managed Markets (powered by Global‑e) makes Global‑e the merchant of record for international sales, so it remits tax to local authorities, manages duties and import tax, and accepts local payment methods. Merchants don’t need local tax registrations in destination countries because Global‑e provides the tax registration and compliance, helping streamline cross‑border taxes and duties.

search_results.title: Information about DAC7 for platform operators
search_results.snippet: Under DAC7, digital platform operators must collect, verify, and report seller information for relevant activities (sale of goods, personal services, and rentals) and submit it annually by January 31 for the prior year. The rules apply to EU and non‑EU platform operators with EU nexus, require detailed seller and transaction data, and impose penalties for non‑compliance—setting expectations for platforms operating in the EU.

search_results.snippet: Möbius (with Shopify Front End) unifies Shopify’s network edge to terminate TLS near users and centralize routing, enabling quicker traffic control and improved reliability. What covenants or restrictions apply to.query: What covenants or restrictions apply to Shopify's debt instruments, and any limitations on repurchases?
What covenants or restrictions apply to.answer: Shopify’s public debt consists of its 0.125% convertible senior notes due 2025, governed by a base indenture and a supplemental indenture. The indenture package contains only limited, customary covenants (e.g., payment of principal/interest, reporting, maintenance of an office/agent) and customary events of default; it does not include maintenance financial covenants or typical high‑yield style restrictions on dividends, equity repurchases, or additional debt incurrence. The supplemental indenture sets note-specific terms, including a “fundamental change” provision requiring Shopify to offer to repurchase the notes at 100% of principal plus accrued interest upon certain events. Any buybacks of Shopify shares are not contractually restricted by these notes and would instead be subject to securities‑market rules (e.g., NCIB limits under TSX policies) rather than debt covenants.

How will Shopify handle merchant request.query: How will Shopify handle merchant requests for payments surcharging and routing under updated regulations?
How will Shopify handle merchant request.answer: Shopify’s official guidance explains that card surcharging is allowed in many jurisdictions but must follow strict rules: notify card networks in advance, clearly disclose fees at entry, checkout, and on receipts, only surcharge credit (not debit), and keep surcharges within legal and network caps. However, Shopify’s checkout doesn’t natively support adding surcharges by payment method, and apps can’t target fees by the selected payment method due to API limits—workarounds are general fees via shipping or pricing. For routing, Shopify Payments (powered by Stripe) implements least‑cost routing in Australia in line with RBA expectations, automatically routing dual‑network debit transactions (e.g., to eftpos) when supported; merchants don’t get granular routing controls, though opt‑out is possible via support.

search_results.snippet: Shopify explains how surcharging must be done under current rules: verify legality by state, follow caps and network rules (e.g., Visa 3%, Mastercard 4%), notify networks 30 days before, disclose fees at entry, checkout, and on receipts, and only surcharge credit—not debit or prepaid. It outlines brand vs. product‑level surcharging and alternative strategies if surcharging isn’t permitted.

search_results.title: Supporting dual-network debit cards in Australia - Stripe Support
search_results.snippet: Stripe (which powers Shopify Payments) states it automatically implements least‑cost routing for Australian merchants, in line with RBA expectations, typically routing dual‑network debit transactions via eftpos where supported. Routing can vary based on technical/authorization factors, and merchants can request to opt out.

report:
# Investment Recommendation Summary
- Stance: BULLISH
- Rating: BUY
- Next market day view: Modestly positive bias. We expect SHOP to trade with a constructive tone next session given sustained growth/FCF momentum, clear 2026 margin expansion levers, and balance sheet strength, absent new macro shocks. Near-term MRR noise from trial changes is known and largely reflected in expectations [1][2][11].

# Executive Summary
Shopify is executing a durable growth and margin expansion playbook: revenue accelerated to 31% in Q2’25 with an eighth consecutive quarter of double-digit FCF margins, alongside guidance that emphasizes disciplined SBC and operating expense control—setting up continued operating leverage into 2026 [1][2]. Payments penetration reached 64% and remains a key monetization driver, supported by rapid geography expansion and enterprise reach (Shop Pay and Adyen partnership) [12][24][28][29][30]. Liquidity is robust ($5.8B+ cash and marketable securities as of Q2’25), with management committed to settling the November 1, 2025 convertible in cash—driving negligible interest expense in 2026 and avoiding dilution [3][5][7][15]. Strategic moves keep checkout inside Shopify (Buy with Prime routed through Shopify Payments), preserving data visibility and attach opportunities [26][27].

Risks are manageable: FX translation, EU payments regulation (PSD3/PSR) timing, and BNPL rule implementation in the U.S./U.K. will require continued compliance investment, while ads monetization remains early and region-limited [10][41][42][31][33][45]. Headcount discipline and AI-driven productivity underpin operating leverage, with management signaling no need for material hiring into 2026 [19][20][21][22][18]. We recommend BUY on the strength of Shopify’s integrated commerce/checkout stack, expanding international payments footprint, enterprise traction, and improving cash profile into 2026.

# Company Overview
Shopify provides commerce infrastructure for businesses to start, run, and scale online and offline stores, monetizing through Subscription Solutions and Merchant Solutions (notably Shopify Payments and Shop Pay), with Plus and POS expanding upmarket and omnichannel reach. FY2024 revenue was $8.88B; management continues to emphasize profitable growth and operating leverage [2].

# Key Findings by Category

## Growth and Revenue
- Broad-based acceleration with Europe outperformance: Q2’25 revenue grew 31% YoY; growth accelerated across North America, Europe, and APAC, with Europe GMV +42% CC—pointing to an expanding international footprint into 2026 [1].  
- Payments as a central growth vector: GPV penetration reached 64% (Q1/Q2’25), sustaining mix-driven Merchant Solutions growth [12][24]. Attach remained on an upward trend through 2023 and into 2024–2025 [14][21].  
- Near-term MRR optics: Shift to three-month paid trials in most geographies will weigh on near-term MRR comparisons; management commentary emphasizes mix/timing rather than broad-based price increases [11].  
- Ads early and region-limited: Shop Campaigns/Shop Ads are deployed in the U.S. and Canada only, with no international timeline or revenue targets disclosed, positioning ads as upside optionality rather than a 2026 base-case driver [31][33][34][35].

## Profitability and Margin Expansion
- Operating discipline intact: Guidance points to SBC pacing ($120–130M in early/mid-2025) and opex ratios stepping down (Q1: 41–42%; Q3: 38–39%), sustaining mid-teens FCF margin—creating visibility into 2026 operating leverage [1][2].  
- Levers to reduce opex as a % of revenue: Keep headcount growth well below revenue growth, enforce disciplined marketing paybacks (~18 months), deploy AI/automation internally, and leverage proprietary systems to size teams efficiently [21][22][18]. Leadership expects to grow GMV/revenue with flat headcount, reinforced by a company-wide AI-first posture [20][19].  
- Mix implications: Subscription Solutions GM remains ~80%, while Merchant Solutions GM is lower (38–40%) due to payments mix/scale; rising payments penetration can compress blended gross margin even as unit economics and revenue scale improve [25][13].

## Liquidity, Capital Allocation, and Interest
- Strong liquidity: Cash and cash equivalents of $1.542B and marketable securities of $4.278B as of June 30, 2025; current convert balance ~$919M [3].  
- No dilution, de minimis 2026 interest: Management intends to settle the $920M November 1, 2025 convertible in cash, implying negligible interest expense post-maturity in 2026 [5][7][15].  
- Capital returns not a priority: No active buyback framework; historical net share issuance and reiterated focus on reinvestment vs. cash returns [16][44][11].

## Strategy and Competition
- Checkout control vs. Amazon: Shopify will allow Buy with Prime inside Shopify Checkout and process via Shopify Payments—retaining payments economics and merchant data inside Shopify’s admin and buyer network [26][27].  
- Enterprise payments push: Multi-year partnership with Adyen as a preferred enterprise payments partner; Shop Pay opened to enterprises not on Shopify—broadening addressable TAM while preserving Shopify’s high-converting checkout advantage [28][29][30].  
- International payments focus (2026): Payments coverage expanded to 39 countries, with 15 new European launches and multicurrency payouts across 20 EU countries; PSD3/PSR timelines imply priority compliance and localization work into 2026 [8][9][10].  
- Shopify Capital internationalization: Now in Germany and the Netherlands; management intent is to expand products across more countries, supporting merchant retention and monetization depth through 2026+ [4].

## Product and AI
- Sidekick AI at global scale: Supports all 20 admin languages and added voice/screen-share, improving merchant productivity and support at scale [36].  
- Pragmatic AI stack: Shopify focuses on fine-tuning smaller open-source multimodal models (e.g., LlaVA, Llama 3.2, Qwen2VL) for cost/accuracy/control, supporting ~40M daily inferences across search, recommendations, and conversational commerce (Sidekick) [37].

## Regulatory, Cybersecurity, and FX
- Payments regulation: EU PSD3/PSR finalization and 18-month transition frame 2026 for member-state readiness; expect compliance engineering uplift in EU markets [10].  
- BNPL rules: U.S. BNPL lenders under Reg Z (effective 2024) and U.K. BNPL authorization regime starts July 15, 2026—Shop Pay Installments partners must meet disclosure, statements, and lending standards [41][42].  
- Security posture: No material cyber incidents disclosed in 2024; PCI DSS Level 1 compliance and quarterly ASV scans continue through June 27, 2026 [39][38].  
- FX sensitivity: Local-currency billing outside North America increases USD translation risk to reported subscription revenue/MRR; Shopify hedges but remains exposed to USD strength vs. CAD/EUR [45].

# Investment Thesis

## Bull Case
- Integrated checkout and rising payments penetration drive sustained Merchant Solutions growth, aided by Europe-first expansion, Shop Pay ubiquity, and enterprise reach (Adyen + Shop Pay for non-Shopify enterprises) [12][24][8][9][28][29][30].  
- Operating leverage compounding into 2026: disciplined SBC/opex, AI-enabled productivity, and flat headcount ambition protect margin expansion and FCF durability [1][2][21][18][20][19].  
- Balance sheet strength and cash settlement of 2025 convert remove dilution and interest overhang into 2026, improving equity value accrual [3][5][7][15].  
- Optionality: Shopify Capital geographic rollout and nascent ads ecosystem offer incremental monetization vectors over time [4][31][35].

## Bear Case
- Mix pressure: Higher payments penetration can weigh on blended gross margins even as revenue scales; lack of disclosed 2026 take-rate/penetration targets injects uncertainty [25][12][13][14][23][24].  
- Ads monetization may remain limited geographically (U.S./Canada only) and timing is uncertain; little visibility on 2026 revenue contribution [31][33][34][35].  
- Regulatory and FX costs: EU PSD3/PSR, U.S./U.K. BNPL standards, and USD strength vs. CAD/EUR may pressure reported growth and require incremental compliance spend [10][41][42][45].  
- Competitive intensity: Stripe and Adyen remain formidable across enterprise, even as partners; Amazon’s Buy with Prime could encroach on Shopify merchants’ sites despite integration terms [28][30][26][27].

# Key Risks
- Macroeconomic sensitivity to consumer demand and SMB formation; longer paid trials can depress near-term MRR optics [11].  
- FX translation headwinds on international billing; hedging is not perfect [45].  
- Payments/regulatory change (PSD3/PSR; BNPL in U.S./U.K.) increasing cost-to-serve and complexity [10][41][42].  
- Execution risk in enterprise (complex migrations, multi-gateway complexity) despite Adyen partnership [28][30].  
- Margin mix risk from accelerating payments penetration and larger-merchant mix [25][13].

# Conclusion and Outlook
- Rating: BUY (BULLISH). Shopify offers a rare mix of high growth, improving cash generation, and visible 2026 margin expansion, underpinned by checkout scale, international payments expansion, enterprise reach, and disciplined opex/SBC [1][2][8][9][28][29][30].  
- Next market day: We expect a modestly positive bias as investors continue to reward the company’s consistent growth/FCF cadence and 2026 deleveraging (no dilution/interest) narrative, with little evidence of new near-term negatives beyond known MRR trial effects [1][2][5][7][11]. Macro factors may still dictate index-relative performance.  
- 12-month outlook: We see continued outperformance driven by payments penetration, Europe/APAC expansion, enterprise wins, and AI-enabled operating leverage. Watch for catalysts including further payments launches, enterprise customer adds via Adyen, Shop Pay adoption outside Shopify, and evidence of sustained mid-teens FCF margins [8][9][28][29][30][1][2].  
- Capital allocation: Expect reinvestment to remain the priority over buybacks/dividends; cash settlement of the 2025 convert simplifies the equity story entering 2026 [15][16][44][5].
